sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: An overwhelming number of frameworks and tooling available today gives the impression that web development has gotten perhaps too complex. Juan Diego Rodríguez explores if web development really is that complex and, most importantly, how we can prevent it from getting even more difficult than we already perceive it to be.
articles.title: Web Development Is Getting Too Complex, And It May Be Our Fault

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: With one billion people aged 60 or older worldwide, inclusivity is more important than ever. Learn how to create digital experiences that empower independence and competence for older adults while enhancing usability for all. An upcoming part of Smart Interface Design Patterns.
articles.title: A Guide To Designing For Older Adults

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Maximillian Piras)
articles.description: As Artificial Intelligence evolves the computing paradigm, designers have an opportunity to craft more intuitive user interfaces. Maximillian Piras examines how the latest AI capabilities can reshape the future of human-computer interaction beyond conversation alone.
articles.title: When Words Cannot Describe: Designing For AI Beyond Conversational Interfaces

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: With February just around the corner, how about a little inspiration boost? We might have one for you: desktop wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Enjoy!
articles.title: 29 Days Of Inspiration (February 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Budd)
articles.description: Most product teams commonly adopt a feature-centric mindset, finding them convenient for brainstorming, drafting requirement documents, and integrating into backlogs and ticketing systems. In this article, Andy Budd shows how fixation with features might be holding you back and how making a few small tweaks to your process could make an entire world of difference.
articles.title: The Feature Trap: Why Feature Centricity Is Harming Your Product

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joas Pambou)
articles.description: Language models have shown impressive capabilities. But that doesn’t mean they’re without faults, as anyone who has witnessed a ChatGPT “hallucination” can attest. In this article, Joas Pambou diagnoses the symptoms that cause hallucinations and explains not only what RAG is but also different approaches for using it to solve language model limitations.
articles.title: A Simple Guide To Retrieval Augmented Generation Language Models

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Yair Even Or)
articles.description: Taking inspiration from shadows, author Yair Even Or creates the same sort of thing, only with a blurring effect in place of the shadow. Read along for a step-by-step explanation of how it comes together using a combination of masks, gradients, and the good ol’ `backdrop-filter` property.
articles.title: CSS Blurry Shimmer Effect

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Filip Paldia & Jamie Clarke)
articles.description: AI promises a major upheaval in typography, with designers finding themselves navigating both opportunities and challenges. How will it impact quality, design roles, and our use of type in the future? As we explore this new frontier, we realise that we are at a juncture as significant as Gutenberg’s press, set to redefine how we interact with text and visual communication.
articles.title: The AI Dilemma In Graphic Design: Steering Towards Excellence In Typography And Beyond

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Temani Afif)
articles.description: The CSS `border-image` property is one of those properties you undoubtedly know exists but may not have ever reached for. In this article, Temani Afif demonstrates different approaches for using `border-image` to create clever decorative accents and shapes.
articles.title: The Complex But Awesome CSS border-image Property

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Louis Lazaris)

articles.description: Ensuring that AI systems are built, deployed, and used safely is critical to our mission.
articles.title: Our approach to AI safety

articles.description: An update on our findings, the actions we’ve taken, and technical details of the bug.
articles.title: March 20 ChatGPT outage: Here’s what happened

articles.description: We’ve implemented initial support for plugins in ChatGPT. Plugins are tools designed specifically for language models with safety as a core principle, and help ChatGPT access up-to-date information, run computations, or use third-party services.
articles.title: ChatGPT plugins
GPTs are GPTs: An early look at the labor market impact potential of large language models

articles.description: We’ve created GPT-4, the latest milestone in OpenAI’s effort in scaling up deep learning. GPT-4 is a large multimodal model (accepting image and text inputs, emitting text outputs) that, while less capable than humans in many real-world scenarios, exhibits human-level performance on various professional and academic benchmarks.
articles.title: GPT-4

articles.author: Shellie Habel
articles.description: OPINION: Sea level rise won’t hit just homes on shorefronts, but also the infrastructure beneath our feet
articles.title: The hidden threat from rising coastal groundwater

articles.author: Tom Siegfried
articles.description: Scientists are probing the head games that influence athletic performance, from coaching to coping with pressure
articles.title: Lessons from sports psychology research

articles.author: Theo Nicitopoulos
articles.description: The detection of two celestial interlopers careening through our solar system have scientists eagerly anticipating more
articles.title: Why interstellar objects like ‘Oumuamua and Borisov may hold clues to exoplanets

articles.author: Ute Eberle
articles.description: The blood-sucking insects now show up in two varieties and are resistant to many pesticides. New eradication strategies include fungal spores and nasty human odors.
articles.title: Getting rid of bed bugs: Trickier than ever

articles.author: Sneha Khedkar
articles.description: Long overlooked, menstrual stem cells could have important medical applications, including diagnosing endometriosis
articles.title: The untapped potential of stem cells in menstrual blood

articles.author: Katarina Zimmer
articles.description: Peoples who live close to nature have a rich lore of plants, animals and landscapes embedded in their mother tongues — which may hold vital clues to protecting biodiversity
articles.title: Indigenous languages are fonts of environmental knowledge

articles.author: Geoff Williams
articles.description: OPINION: International commerce and travel bring ecological destruction to the world’s most cherished natural places. We need to do more to stop the assault.
articles.title: Forests are under attack from invasive species

articles.author: Amber Dance
articles.description: Polygenic risk scores — a patient’s chance, based on tiny DNA variants, of developing cardiovascular disease, breast cancer and more — are coming to clinics. But there are kinks to iron out and accuracy remains an issue.
articles.title: Genes and heart disease: Finally making the link

articles.author: Amber Dance
articles.description: With the first medical therapy approved and systems like CRISPR-Cas showing up in complex cells, there’s a lot going on in the genome editing field. Here’s our primer.
articles.title: CRISPR gene editing: Moving closer to home

articles.author: Lesley Evans Ogden
articles.description: When managed in the right way, the farms that provide our morning brew can be a refuge for plant and animal biodiversity
articles.title: How shade coffee lends conservation a hand

articles.author: Manuel Corpas
articles.description: OPINION: A massive bias in medical studies toward men of European origin means that genetic variants in understudied populations don’t get the focus they deserve
articles.title: We urgently need data for equitable personalized medicine

articles.author: Nicola Jones
articles.description: Twelve standout news events and trends in a tumultuous year
articles.title: Top science stories of 2023

articles.author: Pablo Fonseca Q.
articles.description: Along 1,100 kilometers, from Mexico to Costa Rica, lies the Central American volcanic arc, where the variety of magma types make for a geological paradise
articles.title: Central American volcanoes offer clues to Earth’s geological evolution

articles.author: Viviane Callier
articles.description: Scientists agree that eons ago, a bacterium took up residence inside another cell and became its powerhouse, the mitochondrion. But there are competing theories about the birth of other organelles such as the nucleus and endoplasmic reticulum.
articles.title: Where the heck did all those structures inside complex cells come from?

articles.author: Betsy Mason
articles.description: Our collective arachnid aversion could be causing us to overlook something even scarier: Spiders may be disappearing.
articles.title: Everyone should start counting spiders

articles.author: Daniela Hirschfeld
articles.description: A scientist whose work was key to identifying, studying and finding treatments for this life-threatening virus discusses the scientific journey and challenges that persist
articles.title: The remaining frontiers in fighting hepatitis C

articles.author: Liam Drew
articles.description: Lots of them depend on fruit-eating birds and mammals to spread their seeds. But it’s debatable whether the animals — many in trouble themselves — can disperse seeds far and fast enough to keep pace with a warming world.
articles.title: As the climate changes, plants must shift their ranges. But can they?

articles.author: M. Mitchell Waldrop
articles.description: Scientists have been chasing the dream of harnessing the reactions that power the Sun since the dawn of the atomic era. Interest, and investment, in the carbon-free energy source is heating up.
articles.title: Pursuing fusion power

articles.author: Leslie Carol Roberts
articles.description: As glacial cliffs break off and destabilize frozen landscapes, glaciologist Richard Alley focuses on the fractures. The work could improve predictions about future sea-level rise.
articles.title: The race to understand polar ice sheets

articles.author: Elise Hansen
articles.description: An international treaty aims to bring the shipping industry to net-zero emissions by around 2050. Can novel fuels, wind power and coordination on a global scale get it there?
articles.title: Green shipping picks up speed

articles.author: Tim Vernimmen
articles.description: They have held our fascination ever since we first identified their remains. Today, thanks to new artifacts and technologies, findings about our closest relatives are coming thick and fast.
articles.title: Neanderthals: More knowable now than ever

articles.author: Tim Brinkhof
articles.description: Sea life, stuck to plastic bottles and other human trash, has journeyed far from coastal habitats — and may threaten local species
articles.title: In the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, new marine ecosystems are flourishing

articles.author: Bob Holmes
articles.description: After turning up hundreds of genes with hard-to-predict effects, some scientists are now probing the grander developmental processes that shape face geometry
articles.title: Untangling the genetics that underlie our facial features

articles.description: Plus, plastic brings critters from coasts to open waters
articles.title: Anatomy of an ice shelf, and space lasers

articles.author: John Johnson Jr.
articles.description: The first tests of optical communications far from Earth will take place aboard the asteroid-bound Psyche spacecraft
articles.title: Speedy downloads: Why NASA is turning to lasers for next-gen space comms

articles.author: Katarina Zimmer
articles.description: As wind power grows around the world, so does the threat the turbines pose to wildlife. From simple fixes to high-tech solutions, new approaches can help.
articles.title: How wind turbines could coexist peacefully with bats and birds

articles.author: Jude Coleman
articles.description: Stronger than plastic and tougher than glass, the resin-filled material is being exploited for smartphone screens, insulated windows and more
articles.title: Why scientists are making transparent wood

articles.author: Rina Diane Caballar
articles.description: DNA sequencing, GPS tracking and tailored diets are slowly restoring the endangered kākāpō
articles.title: New Zealand’s quest to save its rotund, flightless parrots

articles.author: David Levin
articles.description: Growing evidence suggests a link between the debilitating neurological illness and the microbes that live in our intestines. The vagus nerve may be a pathway.
articles.title: How gut bacteria connect to Parkinson’s disease

articles.author: Tim Vernimmen
articles.description: New research suggests that to maintain a healthy brain, we should tend our gut microbiome. The best way to do that right now is not through pills and supplements, but better food.
articles.title: The growing link between microbes, mood and mental health
